ai.harmony.ravel.compiler.scope

Interface Scope

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    BaseScope, ComponentSymbol, ControllerSymbol, EventHandlerSymbol, GlobalScope, InterfaceSymbol, LocalScope, MethodDeclarationSymbol, ModelSymbol, SpaceSymbol, SymbolWithScope, ViewSymbol

    public interface Scope
    A scope is a dictionary of symbols that are grouped together by some lexical construct in the input language. Examples include structs, functions, {...} code blocks, argument lists, etc... Scopes all have an enclosing scope that encloses them lexically. In other words, am I wrapped in a class? a function? a {...} code block? This is distinguished from the parent scope. The parent scope is usually the enclosing scope, but in the case of inheritance, it is the superclass rather than the enclosing scope. Otherwise, the global scope would be considered the parent scope of a class. When resolving symbols, we look up the parent scope chain not the enclosing scope chain. For convenience of code using this library, I have added a bunch of methods one can use to get lots of useful information from a scope, but they don't necessarily define what a scope is.

    • Method Detail

      • getName

        java.lang.String getName()
        Often scopes have names like function or class names. For unnamed scopes like code blocks, you can just return "local" or something.

      • getDefNode

        org.antlr.v4.runtime.ParserRuleContext getDefNode()
        The AST node that defines this scope (for error messages)

      • getEnclosingScope

        Scope getEnclosingScope()
        Scope in which this scope defined. null if no enclosing scope

      • setEnclosingScope

        void setEnclosingScope(Scope s)
        What scope encloses this scope. E.g., if this scope is a function, the enclosing scope could be a class. The BaseScope class automatically adds this to nested scope list of s.

      • define

        void define(Symbol sym)
     throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Define a symbol in this scope, throw IllegalArgumentException if sym already defined in this scope. This alters sym: 1. Set insertion order number of sym 2. Set sym's scope to be the scope. The order in which symbols are defined must be preserved so that getSymbols() returns the list in definition order.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

      • resolve

        Symbol resolve(java.lang.String name)
        Look up name in this scope or recursively in parent scope if not here

      • getSymbol

        Symbol getSymbol(java.lang.String name)
        Get symbol if name defined within this specific scope

      • nest

        void nest(Scope scope)
   throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Add a nested local scope to this scope; it's like define() but for non SymbolWithScope objects. E.g., a FunctionSymbol will add a LocalScope for its block via this method.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if you pass in a SymbolWithScope.

      • getNestedScopes

        java.util.List<Scope> getNestedScopes()
        Return a list of scopes nested within this scope. It has both ScopedSymbols and scopes without symbols, such as LocalScopes. This returns a superset or same set as getNestedScopedSymbols(). ScopedSymbols come first then all non-ScopedSymbols Scope objects. Insertion order is used within each sublist.

      • getNestedScope

        Scope getNestedScope(java.lang.String name)
        get scope by name
        Parameters:
        name -
        Returns:

      • hasNestedScope

        boolean hasNestedScope(java.lang.String name)
        verify if the nested scope has been defined
        Parameters:
        name -
        Returns:

      • getEnclosingPathToRoot

        java.util.List<Scope> getEnclosingPathToRoot()
        Return (inclusive) list of all scopes on path to root scope. The first element is the current scope and the last is the root scope.

      • getNestedScopedSymbols

        java.util.Collection<Scope> getNestedScopedSymbols()
        Return all immediately enclosed scoped symbols in insertion order. E.g., a class would return all nested classes and any methods. There does not have to be an explicit pointer to the nested scopes. This method generally searches the list of symbols looking for symbols that implement Scope. Gets only those scopes that are in the symbols list of "this" scope. E.g., does not get local scopes within a function. This returns a subset or same set as getNestedScopes().

      • getSymbols

        java.util.Collection<Symbol> getSymbols()
        Return the symbols defined within this scope. The order of insertion into the scope is the order returned in this list.

      • getAllSymbols

        java.util.Collection<Symbol> getAllSymbols()
        Return all symbols found in all nested scopes. The order of insertion into the scope is the order returned in this list for each scope. The scopes are traversed in the order in which they are encountered in the input.

      • getSymbolNames

        java.util.Set<java.lang.String> getSymbolNames()
        Return the set of names associated with all symbols in the scope.

      • getNumberOfSymbols

        int getNumberOfSymbols()
        Number of symbols in this specific scope

      • toQualifierString

        java.lang.String toQualifierString(java.lang.String separator)
        Return scopes from to current with separator in between
